governance_styles.description: Systems where supreme power is concentrated in the hands of one person.

types.name: Monarchy
types.description: Rule by a single person (monarch) who typically inherits their position (e.g., King, Queen, Emperor, Sultan).

sub_types.name: Absolute Monarchy
sub_types.description: The monarch holds supreme, unrestricted power.

sub_types.name: Constitutional Monarchy
sub_types.description: The monarch's powers are limited by a constitution, often serving a ceremonial role with real power held by elected officials.

types.name: Dictatorship
types.description: Rule by a single leader (dictator) who has absolute power, typically obtained and maintained through force, not inheritance. Often suppresses opposition.

governance_styles.description: Systems where power rests with a small number of people.

types.name: Oligarchy (General)
types.description: Rule by a small group. The basis for their power can vary.

types.name: Aristocracy
types.description: Rule by a hereditary noble class or perceived 'best' citizens.

types.name: Junta
types.description: Rule by a small group of military leaders, often after a coup d'Ã©tat.

types.name: Theocracy
types.description: Rule by religious leaders or based directly on religious law and doctrine.

types.name: Technocracy
types.description: Rule by technical experts or scientists.

governance_styles.description: Systems where the ultimate power is held by the people.

types.name: Direct Democracy
types.description: Citizens vote directly on laws and policies.

types.name: Representative Democracy
types.description: Citizens elect representatives to make decisions on their behalf. Often takes the form of a Republic.

sub_types.name: Republic
sub_types.description: A state where supreme power is held by the people and their elected representatives, and which has an elected or nominated president rather than a monarch.

sub_types.name: Parliamentary System
sub_types.description: The executive branch derives its legitimacy from and is accountable to the legislature; executive and legislative branches are intertwined.

sub_types.name: Presidential System
sub_types.description: The executive branch is elected separately from the legislature, and both branches have distinct powers.

sub_types.name: Semi-Presidential System
sub_types.description: Features both a President (usually head of state) and a Prime Minister (usually head of government accountable to the legislature).

governance_styles.description: Systems characterized by the absence of a formal governing authority.

types.name: Anarchy
types.description: A state of society without a governing authority or hierarchy. Can imply disorder, or a system based on voluntary cooperation.

related_concepts.name: Totalitarianism
related_concepts.description: A style where the state attempts to exert total control over nearly every aspect of public and private life. Can overlay different forms like Dictatorships.
related_concepts.relevance: Describes the extent and nature of state control, applicable across various government forms.

related_concepts.name: Authoritarianism
related_concepts.description: Demands obedience to authority with less control over personal life than totalitarianism. Can apply to various non-democratic forms.
related_concepts.relevance: Describes the enforcement of state authority, applicable across various government forms.

related_concepts.name: Structural Power Distribution
related_concepts.description: Describes how power is distributed geographically within a state.

sub_concepts.name: Federal State
sub_concepts.description: Power is divided between a central government and regional/state governments.

related_concepts.relevance: Applies to how various government forms (especially Republics) are organized geographically.

related_concepts.name: Tribal Governance
related_concepts.description: Traditional forms of governance in tribal societies, which can include chiefs (monarchy-like), councils of elders (oligarchy/gerontocracy), or consensus-based community decisions (democracy-like).
related_concepts.relevance: Specific context often found in smaller-scale societies or indigenous groups.
